headline: Manchester United have broken their own transfer rule for a second time - but it makes sense
body: If it was Manchester United's plan to banish the demons generated by their Europa League final defeat to Tottenham Hotspur five weeks ago via the transfer window, it's working.
After wrapping up the £62.5million signing of Matheus Cunha from Wolves exactly a fortnight ago, United are now closing in on the signing of Brentford attacker Bryan Mbeumo.

It is understood a deal is edging closer towards being finalised after United submitted a new and improved offer in excess of £60m earlier this week. Barring any late snags or hiccups, he will become the club's second signing of the summer.

United went into this summer's window with no choice but loosen their purse strings after a forgettable 2024/25 campaign marked their worst season in 51 years. However, few anticipated they would be as ambitious as they have been in the opening weeks of the window.

United announced they had reached an agreement with Wolves to sign Cunha just 14 hours after the transfer window had opened on June 1, ensuring they put down an early marker, and now they are closing in on the signing of Mbeumo less than four weeks later.
Defeat in Bilbao was supposedly going to hinder United's ability in this summer's transfer window. Instead, it has given them the jolt they needed.

It goes without saying that two signings won't be enough for United this summer, and they will need to bring in more faces once they flex their muscles in the seller's market, but to have Cunha and potentially Mbeumo through the door by the end of June is admirable.

United finished last season's Premier League campaign with a negative goal difference of -10, meaning they needed to commit funds to strengthening their attacking department. After missing out on Champions League qualification, it felt as though attracting big-name players would be a struggle.

However, United have been reminded by both Cunha and Mbeumo that they will always be a powerhouse. Cunha had his heart set on a move to Old Trafford for months and Mbeumo has followed suit by prioritising a move to M16 over Tottenham Hotspur.

The elephant in the room, however, is that once the deal to bring Mbeumo to Old Trafford gets over the line, United will have spent north of £120m on the duo. Considering sales are expected to dictate what is possible for United this summer, the Reds have certainly shown plenty of ambition early on amid the fact they are yet to oversee a single outgoing.
Cunha is the first signing of the Ineos era to have cost more than £60m. United brought in five new signings last summer and Leny Yoro was the most expensive addition at a base price of £52.2m.

After years of being taken for a ride in the market, United have become a little bit wiser under Ineos' governance, refusing to pay over the odds. Sir Jim Ratcliffe admitted last year that he would prefer to discover a hidden gem "rather than spend a fortune just trying to buy success".

You could argue Ratcliffe has contradicted himself by allowing United to sign Cunha for £62.5m and lodge a bid worth more than £60m for Mbeumo. However, every club that shares the same ambitions as United has to splash the cash every once in a while to strengthen their squad.

United will be unable to preside over many more £60m-plus deals this summer. In fact, they may not be able to preside over another if they are unable to offload the likes of Marcus Rashford, Jadon Sancho, Alejandro Garnacho and Antony.

Nevertheless, they have made an exception to their own rule to get Cunha through the door and attempt to sign Mbeumo, and it does make sense this time around. Their attack was in a sorry state last season and they could not afford to do nothing about it this summer.

Cunha scored 17 goals last season across all competitions, and Mbeumo plundered 20 in the Premier League. Between them, their tally of 35 in the league was only nine fewer than what United scored as a collective.

With that in mind, United are right to have settled on them as two of their priority targets. There is no guarantee they will be successes at Old Trafford just in the same way no managerial appointment is ever guaranteed to pay off.
But in choosing to try and recruit two attackers with Premier League pedigree, United are trying to make up for last season's failings in the best possible way.

headline: Manchester United are only two signings away from their dream XI after Bryan Mbeumo breakthrough
body: After Manchester United lost last month's Europa League final in Bilbao, supporters would have been forgiven for feeling somewhat deflated heading into this summer's transfer window.

United's 1-0 defeat to Tottenham spelt the end of their hopes of qualifying for next season's Champions League. It means they will be absent from Europe for the first time since the 2014/15 campaign next term.

Despite that, United have started this summer's transfer window on the front foot. After wrapping up the signing of Wolves star Matheus Cunha earlier this month, they are now closing in on Brentford's Bryan Mbeumo.

After tabling a second offer in excess of £60million earlier this week, it is understood United are now making progress in their attempts to bring him to M16. The club hope to have him signed ahead of pre-season starting in just under a fortnight's time.
Mbeumo was nothing short of outstanding for Brentford last term, scoring 20 Premier League goals. He also contributed seven assists.

Although United have attempted to distance themselves from paying north of £60m for players under Ineos, they have made an exception to their own transfer rule with the addition of Cunha for £62.5m and their pursuit of Mbeumo.

However, the duo, who scored 35 Premier League goals between them last season, are Premier League proven and will slot straight into Ruben Amorim's first-choice starting XI. Cunha is expected to occupy the left-sided No.10 berth but where Amorim sees Mbeumo's natural habitat at Old Trafford remains to be seen.

Whether he starts as a No.10 or at wing-back, Amad will almost certainly fill the role Mbeumo does not. The Ivorian should be one of the very first names on the teamsheet next term after a very encouraging 2024/25 campaign.

United had to prioritise strengthening their attack this summer and getting a deal over the line for Cunha nice and early was a solid start. The prospect of also having Mbeumo in the building by the start of pre-season would represent an excellent start.

However, United are yet to lay their hands on a striker. Their hopes of signing Liam Delap were scuppered by Chelsea and it remains to be seen who they will turn to in their quest for a No.9. The addition of a striker will be the last piece to add to their attacking jigsaw.
Currently well-stocked at centre-back, defensive reinforcements are not required this summer unless something drastic changes. In midfield, however, there is a hunger to strengthen.

Amorim wants to add a new central midfielder of an athletic profile. Bruno Fernandes is expected to become a long-term operator in one of the two No.8 positions, meaning he could be in need of a new partner.

Manuel Ugarte experienced an up and down first season at United and his ability on the ball has been questioned in recent months. In an ideal situation, United need to strike a fine balance between being defensively sound and good on the ball.

Kobbie Mainoo flittered between midfield and the No.10 positions last season, suggesting Amorim is yet to decide on his long-term role. The England international likes to play on the front foot and progress the ball, meaning he is not necessarily the right partner for Fernandes in a midfield two.
The additions of a striker and a midfielder will be United's top priorities once Mbeumo is in the building, but sales will be key to ensuring those deals can be completed.
But with the window still open for another nine-and-a-half weeks, there is plenty of time for Amorim's dream XI to come to fruition.

headline: Manchester United can take advantage of shock situation to solve major transfer problem
body: French football was left stunned on Tuesday evening by the bombshell news that seven-time French champions Lyon have been relegated from Ligue 1.
The French giants have been demoted to Ligue 2 after failing to convince authorities they have resolved their financial difficulties.

Lyon were hit with a provisional relegation back in November after racking up massive debts, and although they have since sold a number of first-team players, French football watchdog the DNCG upheld the relegation following meetings on Tuesday.

They have since confirmed they will appeal the verdict, branding it an 'incomprehensible decision'. It means it could still be overturned but if the relegation is upheld, Lyon would be replaced in the top flight by Reims, who lost the relegation play-off to Metz.
Manchester United have launched their new home kit for the 2025/26 season with an Adidas shirt paying tribute to Old Trafford.
Fans can order their Men's, Women's and Kid's shirt today.
It will have a huge effect on football throughout Europe, with Lyon finishing sixth in Ligue 1 last season and looking set to compete in next season's Europa League.
Lyon, of course, played Manchester United in a memorable Europa League quarter-final last season but they will forfeit the right to compete in the competition next season if the appeal is upheld.
It will have a catastrophic effect on their playing squad, too, with clubs now monitoring their best players in case they are relegated from the French top flight.
United could be one of those clubs prepared to pounce and it could present them with a unique opportunity to solve a big transfer problem for a cut-price fee.

It is no secret United are in the market for a new centre-forward. They courted Liam Delap before his move to Chelsea was confirmed and Ruben Amorim is desperate to improve a blunt United attack that managed just 44 Premier League goals last term.
Georges Mikautadze announced himself to during last summer's European Championship in Germany while playing for Georgia.
In his country's first major tournament, Mikautadze scored in all three group games and has translated that form to club level this term.
The 24-year-old scored 17 goals in all competitions last season - which is the same number as Rasmus Hojlund and Joshua Zirkzee managed combined - and added a further 11 assists.
Mikautadze plays mainly as a centre-forward but can also play as a 10 or on the wing, giving him the versatility that United CEO Omar Berrada has said the club are looking for with any new recruits.
He still has three years remaining on his contract with Lyon but should their relegation to Ligue 2 be confirmed it will likely spark a mass exodus of their top talent.
United could do a lot worse than using their plight to their advantage when it comes to their forward search.

headline: 10 players out of contract next summer who can solve Manchester United transfer priorities now
body: Manchester United have already been busy in the summer transfer market as they look to give Ruben Amorim the tools to go about his United rebuild in his first full season in charge.
Matheus Cunha has already arrived from Wolves in a £62.5million transfer, while Bryan Mbeumo is edging closer to a move to Old Trafford after United submitted a second bid for the Brentford star.
The pair will fill United's attacking midfield slots next season but they could still be in the market for a new centre-forward, centre-midfielder, wing-back and goalkeeper this summer.
With that in mind, we have picked out 10 players out of contract in 2026 who United could look to buy this summer to solve some of their transfer priorities.
Manchester United have launched their new home kit for the 2025/26 season with an Adidas shirt paying tribute to Old Trafford.
Fans can order their Men's, Women's and Kid's shirt today.
Mbeumo's contract runs out at Brentford next summer and, as previously mentioned, United are desperate to secure his signature this summer.
United tabled a new and improved bid in excess of £60million for the Cameroon international after an opening offer worth £55million was turned down earlier this month.
The 25-year-old scored 20 Premier League goals for the Bees last season and will help to sharpen United's blunt attack.
There hasn't been a summer transfer window for years that United haven't been linked with a move for the Barcelona midfielder.
Erik ten Hag was desperate to be reunited with his former Ajax midfielder at Old Trafford but since Amorim has replaced the Dutchman, those links have gone colder.
That being said, the two-time La Liga winner would still be an excellent addition to this United side and his situation this summer is one to watch.
United need a forward and Vlahovic is said to be available as he has failed to agree terms on a new contract with Juventus.
The Serbian international scored 16 goals in all competitions last term, just one less than Rasmus Hojlund and Joshua Zirkzee managed combined.
The 25-year-old still has his best years ahead of him and would be an instant upgrade on United's current forward options.
Like Mbeumo, Wissa scored plenty of goals for Brentford last season and is attracting interest from elsewhere in the Premier League.
The DR Congo international bagged 20 goals in all competitions and can play right across the forward line. At 28, he is perhaps just about hitting his prime, too.
Bentancur is yet to agree new terms with Tottenham and would offer proven Premier League quality.
The 28-year-old is international team-mates with United midfielder Manuel Ugarte for Uruguay and is a serial trophy winner.
Having helped Tottenham beat United to win last season's Europa League, he has also won seven major trophies with Juventus and three with Boca Juniors.
Maignan has proven himself as one of European football's best goalkeepers, both with AC Milan and the France national team.
Still aged just 29, he is young for a goalkeeper and has attracted interest from Chelsea already this summer. Few could argue he would not be an upgrade on Andre Onana.
United were routinely linked with Neves while he was at Wolves but, ultimately, he ended up moving to Saudi Pro League outfit Al-Hilal.
The Portugal international midfielder, 28, is entering the final year of his three-year deal with the club and could be tempted by a return to top level European football.
Brandt has spent his entire career in Germany across spells with Bayer Leverkusen and Borussia Dortmund but his qualities should translate to the Premier League.
The 29-year-old Germany international can operate anywhere across the midfield and is yet to pen fresh terms at Signal Iduna Park.
The Nigeria international, 28, recently triggered an extension to remain at the City Ground until the end of next season but has not penned fresh terms beyond that yet.
The twin brother of Arsenal defender, Jurrien, Quinten Timber is a combative midfielder who has impressed for both Feyenoord and the Netherlands.
Liverpool boss Arne Slot has waxed lyrical about the qualities the 24-year-old possesses and he could prove to be a shrewd addition in midfield.

headline: Man United transfer news LIVE - Bryan Mbeumo close, Jadon Sancho agreement, Garnacho latest
body: The Reds are looking to add new faces to their squad after completing a deal for Matheus Cunha earlier in the window. The club are working hard behind the scenes, with a new striker now said to be the top priority.
Brentford star Bryan Mbeumo looks as though he'll be the next summer signing through the door, with United reportedly beating Spurs to his signature.
United are expected to spend big on the Cameroonian international, with the 25-year-old on the brink of a £60m move to Old Trafford in another statement of intent.
However, the Reds know they need to offload a number of big name stars as part of Ruben Amorim's rebuild, with Andrea Onana among those who faces an uncertain future at the club.
Meanwhile, Casemiro, Jadon Sancho, Marcus Rashford, and Alejandro Garnacho could also be on the move this summer as part of a major squad overhaul.

The former Borussia Dortmund star, who spent last season on loan at Chelsea, could help United get their hands on a couple of new faces. Sancho has reportedly turned heads in the Serie A, so a swap deal could be on the cards.
Jonathan David, who has been linked with Man United this summer, has been offered the chance to move to Juventus this summer.
Sky Italia have claimed the Old Lady have put an offer on the table for the 25-year-old, who is said to be keen on a move to Italy. Napoli are also said to be keen.
Paris Saint-Germain midfielder Warren Zaire-Emery is reportedly on Man United's radar with a move for the Frenchman being explored, according to reports.
TEAMtalk has claimed that exploratory contacts have been made to PSG with the European champions wanting around £85million for his signature.
PSG are said to be keen to keep him.
Juventus are reportedly closing in on an agreement with United to sign Jadon Sancho.
Reports in Italy have claimed the agreement could come in the next few hours with the Old Lady winning the three-horse race between themselves, Fenerbahce and Napoli.
Sky Italy have claimed Juve will hold talks with his representatives imminently to try and get the deal over the line.
Outgoing United defender Sam Murray has joined Carlisle United on a one-year deal.
The left-back is one of nine players who will officially leave Old Trafford when his contract expires on Monday (June 30).
His move to Cumbria will see him link up with former United ace Mark Hughes. Murray failed to make his senior debut during his told at Old Trafford.
Bryan Mbeumo is close to joining Man United but Ruben Amorim's side aren't expected to be finished there.
The Times have reported that United are in the market for a striker, wing-back, midfielder and goalkeeper. However, adding those reinforcements relies heavily on player sales.
Newcastle are showing strong interest in Marcus Rashford this summer with Caught Offside claiming the EFL Cup holders are making 'serious moves' to sign him.
The Magpies recently failed with a bid for Antony Elanga and it's said that Rashford is on their radar. The report states that they are keen on a loan deal for Rashford.

Gazzetta dello Sport claim Inter Milan are in constant contact with Manchester United regarding a potential move for Rasmus Hojlund this summer. The Danish international struggled in front of goal last season and United could sell the 22-year-old in an attempt to revamp their squad.

Although Inter are closing in on a deal to sign Parma’s Ange-Yoan Bonny, the Champions League finalists believe Hojlund can bolster their attack. United's reported asking price of €45million (£38.38m) is said to be too high for Inter, but the Italian side could propose a loan deal with an option or conditional obligation to buy.
The Serie A side believe that Hojlund's valuation will be lower in a year given United will have amortised more of the the player's transfer fee.
Former Manchester United striker Odion Ighalo believes Napoli ace Victor Osimhen is one of the best centre-forwards in the world amid ongoing speculation linking him with a move to Old Trafford.
Osimhen is continuing to be linked with a move to M16 amid United's desperate need to sign a striker in this summer's transfer window.

Napoli are planning to sell the 26-year-old this summer after he returned from a successful season-long loan spell at Galatasaray. He joined the Turkish club last September after falling out with Napoli boss Antonio Conte and scored 37 goals in 41 games.
Galatasaray want to sign him on a permanent basis and recently informed him they would like him to make a decision on his future as quickly as possible.
You can read more here.

Benfica president Rui Costa says Real Madrid are yet to approach the Portuguese club with a bid to sign former Manchester United defender Alvaro [Fernandez] Carreras. The 22-year-old joined Benfica last summer after United agreed a deal to join Bruno Lage's side for a reported £5million last summer having failed to break into the United first-team set-up.

Carreras was highly rated during his time at Old Trafford, enjoying a number of successful loan spells away from the club with Preston North End, Granada and Benfica, before making the move to Portugal permanent last summer.

United signed the Spanish full back from Real Madrid in 2020 and his former club are reportedly keen on signing him again this summer. Ruben Amorim's side were also linked with a transfer swoop for the former academy talent, having impressed with Benfica last season.

Carreras made 52 appearances in all competitions for the Primeira Liga side last season, scoring four goals and is part of the Benfica squad currently in action in the Club World Cup. It's in that tournament, that Spanish publication Marca spoke with the player and Benfica president Costa about Real's reported interest in the player.
You can read more here.
Manchester United continue to be linked with a number of big name signings across all areas of the pitch as Ruben Amorim looks to put his own stamp on the squad.

The Portuguese head coach was unable to add to his team the way he would have liked in the January transfer market, and after a disappointing campaign, the United hierarchy are giving Amorim their full support this summer.
With that in mind, here are your Manchester United early morning headlines:
French football was left stunned on Tuesday evening by the bombshell news that seven-time French champions Lyon have been relegated from Ligue 1.
The French giants have been demoted to Ligue 2 after failing to convince authorities they have resolved their financial difficulties.

Lyon were hit with a provisional relegation back in November after racking up massive debts, and although they have since sold a number of first-team players, French football watchdog the DNCG upheld the relegation following meetings on Tuesday.

They have since confirmed they will appeal the verdict, branding it an 'incomprehensible decision'. It means it could still be overturned but if the relegation is upheld, Lyon would be replaced in the top flight by Reims, who lost the relegation play-off to Metz.
You can read more here.
Manchester United's summer transfer business is ramping up with Bryan Mbeumo closing in on becoming Ruben Amorim's second signing of the window.

Despite interest from Newcastle United and Tottenham, the 25-year-old has given his preference to United and the club want to get him signed before the start of pre-season. United's second offer for Mbeumo - thought to be in the region of £60million - is not far off Brentford's valuation.

Elsewhere, United, who have made one first-team addition in the form of Matheus Cunha this summer, want to sign another midfielder. Leicester City's Wilfred Ndidi has emerged as a target, with the Nigerian midfielder having a £9m release clause in his contract after the Foxes were relegated to the Championship.
Brentford star Bryan Mbeumo has reportedly made it clear that a move to Manchester United is his dream move amid ongoing negotiations between the two Premier League clubs.
Journalist Fabrizio Romano claims the Cameroon international has made it clear that he wishes to join the Reds this summer with United keen to get a deal done as soon as possible.
Speaking on his YouTube channel, Romano said:

"Manchester United maintain their optimism to reach an agreement for Bryan Mbeumo, because they have an agreement with the player. What I can add today, is the player is also being clear with Brentford. He loves Brentford and has a fantastic relationship with people at the club. The manager has left but it's about the staff, the management, the teammates.

Mbeumo is really in a great relationship but he's been clear in telling them that going to Manchester United is a dream move. He would like to go to Man United as soon as possible. They improved their bid in recent days from what I heard over the weekend, a new bid was sent in excess of £60million package.
Man United are trying to get it done as soon as possible, negotiations are underway and they are confident Mbeumo will be the second arrival after Matheus Cunha."
Outgoing defender Victor Lindelof says he'll always be a fan of Manchester United after his departure from the clib was confirmed.

"I've had so many good memories here," he told MUTV. "Just looking at the Stretford End here, I mean, I'm going to miss it a lot. They're [the fans] with us through absolutely everything, and it doesn't matter the result, every single week, they come here and they support us and they sing their souls out.

"I just want to say thank you so much for taking me in. I'm leaving as a player, but I will always be a fan," the defender confirmed. I wish nothing but the best for the guys and everyone around the club.
"Yeah, hopefully next season will be a little better than this one. I'm very sure it's going to be."
Vasco Moreira, a former Porto youth player, has acknowledged he would like to one day play for United.
In an interview with the Portuguese sports newspaper Record, the defensive midfielder currently playing in the country's second-tier said:

Manchester United, I would like to play there and feel the energy of Old Trafford; it is a stage that has a certain quality. I have some teams that I would like to be part of, but I think that depends on me; I like to think more about the championships and then work, and only then will I see where I will go.

Moving from Portugal to a big club in Europe would be difficult, but I don't have any reservations. At the moment, I am contractually tied to Felgueiras, and that will happen, but things change quickly in football.

I have this goal: I want to prove myself at a high level. I don't know if it will be soon or in four years; I won't rest until I achieve it. It doesn't just depend on me, but on a number of factors, but I'm calm.
United reportedly accept that their £60million valuation of Alejandro Garnacho is unlikely to be met.

The Mirror now claims a fee of around £40million would be more realistic. They also cite sources when claiming the player posting a photo on social media wearing an Aston Villa shirt with 'Rashford' on the back has only hardened their stance on selling him.
Viktor Gyokeres has reportedly told United he wants to sign for them this summer.

TEAMtalk cites sources when claiming Old Trafford is now his destination of choice, regardless of interest from other clubs. United head coach Ruben Amorim is also said to be determined to add another striker next season.
Sporting CP are reportedly prioritising Luis Javier Suarez as their priority target to replace Viktor Gyokeres.

Fabrizio Romano claims the Almeria striker is top of their short list and is who they want as their new number nine. The Portuguese club identifying their standout choice could suggest Gyokeres is closer than ever to leaving.
Tolu Arokodare has admitted to being a United fan and acknowledges that any move to the club would mean a lot to him and his family.
The striker has told SportsBoom:
Obviously, it's a dream to play in the Premier League, and I have my eyes on it for sure. Whatever options I have, I'll take my time and make the best decision.
I'm a Manchester United fan, and if it happens, it would mean a lot to me and my family.
Kobbie Mainoo is said to have held positive talks over his United future with Ruben Amorim since the end of last season.

GiveMeSport claims a move during this summer transfer window is now increasingly unlikely. United reputedly have no interest in considering a possible move and still want the player to sign a new contract.
There is reportedly no firm interest from other clubs in Tyrell Malacia yet at this stage of the summer transfer window.
The Athletic claims United are struggling to attract suitors for the left-back. Malacia spent the second half of last season on loan at PSV and won the Eredivisie while in Eindhoven.
Ruben Amorim's search for a new Manchester United No.1 could come to an end this summer should a deal be struck for Porto ace Diogo Costa.
A Bola reports that Costa will leave the Portuguese giants this summer in search of a 'new challenge.'
It is also suggested that he 'dreams' of playing in England, and both United, as well as rivals Manchester City, are interested in his services. Costa has a £64m exit clause in his contract.

A replacement for Costa had now been lined up by his current side, as TV Azteca report that Cruz Azul's goalkeeper Kevin Mier is on Porto's shortlist and has been prioritised by club president Andre Villas-Boas.
It is also alleged that Porto manager Martin Anselmi is familiar with the player and has personally recommended his signing.
Former Manchester United forward Cristiano Ronaldo is set to sign a new contract at Al-Nassr, according to Fabrizio Romano. Final details on the 40-year-old's deal is being checked and prepared.
A one or two year contract is on the table for Ronaldo, and there is a 'concrete possibility' that the Portugal international remains in the Saudi Pro League until he is at least 42.
Manchester United have held talks with the representatives of Club Brugge midfielder Ardon Jashari, while AC Milan have taken the more direct approach with a €30million (£25.6million) bid tabled.

Premier League rivals Fulham and West Ham are, also, said to have placed the 22-year-old among their own top targets, with either of their advances so far rejected. Manchester City were flagged up in the same conversation, before electing to pay £46.3million for Milan's Tijjani Reijnders.
Reports emerged earlier this week that Arne Slot's side were exploring a potential move for Gyokeres, 27, after he scored 54 goals and added 13 assists in 52 matches during the 2024/25 season.
However, TNT have now claimed that the Reds do not plan on making a move for the Sweden international this summer, giving United a major boost in their pursuit.
Manchester United have set their sights on signing Lille goalkeeper Lucas Chevalier, according to TEAMtalk.
Ruben Amorim's side are expected to dip into the transfer market for a new shot-stopper and Chevalier has been identified as their top target if Andre Onana leaves the club.
Chevalier impressed during his 48 appearances for Lille last term, putting in standout performances in the Champions League and being named the Ligue 1 Goalkeeper of the Season.
Juventus are holding a video call with Manchester United today to try and work out a deal for Jadon Sancho, according to Calciomercato.
It's added that Sancho is 'back in fashion' at Juve, who are talking to United over a deal for the England international. The Serie A side are pushing hard to sign the 25-year-old this summer.
Manchester United are edging closer to a full agreement with Brentford over the transfer of Bryan Mbeumo, according to talkSPORT.
It emerged on Tuesday that United are nearing to a £60million deal for Mbeumo, who had a superb season in 2024/25, finishing with 20 goals and eight assists across all competitions.
Now, talkSPORT reporter Alex Crook has claimed that Mbeumo's move to United is on the verge of completion, despite rumours claiming that Tottenham are planning to hijack the move.
Football Insider claim Man United-linked Emi Martinez has his 'heart set' on a move to Atletico Madrid.
As a result, they are said to have turned to Lille shot-stopper Lucas Chevalier and are 'weighing up' a move for the Frenchman. The report notes that he is valued at around £40m.
Lindelof says he will always continue supporting Man United after leaving the club this summer.

"A perfect ending," Lindelof told MUTV. "Clean sheet and a win, so it was a great ending. To spend it with my family here [on the pitch afterwards], as well, was special. So, yeah, I couldn't have asked for a better ending.

"Yeah, I am proud of myself," the defender continued. "It's been a lot of ups and downs. "But I mean, for me to be able to represent this club for eight years, it's been an honour and a privilege, and a dream come true."
The defender's next steps remain uncertain, but he will continue to support United as a fan. "I'm leaving as a player, but I will always be a fan," the defender stated.
"I wish nothing but the best for the guys and everyone around the club. Yeah, hopefully next season will be a little better than this one. I'm very sure it's going to be."

headline: £159m tipping point, Bryan Mbeumo transfer demand - Man United must act fast as fresh deadline looms
body: It might not feel like it but the new Premier League season is just 50 days away.

It represents a fresh start for Manchester United after the domestic woes of the 2024-25 campaign. The Reds finished a dismal 15th in the table and missed the chance to save their season when losing to Tottenham in the Europa League final.
United have set a target of being a top six side next term and Ruben Amorim knows a strong start is crucial as he prepares for his first full season in charge.
The Reds have acted swiftly in the transfer market to sign Mathues Cunha from Wolves for £62.5million and are set to complete a deal for Brentford's Bryan Mbeumo in the coming days.
That would take spending past the £120m mark and United will then turn their attention to sales as they seek to offload unwanted quartet Marcus Rashford, Alejandro Garnacho, Jadon Sancho and Antony.

Shifting those four on, and recouping significant income, will help United's quest to sign a new centre forward while the Reds may look at other areas of the squad ahead of the window closing on September 1.
We take a look at three key aspects of the next seven weeks.
Getting Mbeumo over the line in time for the start of pre-season would be a significant step for United.
Having him and Cunha in the building early allows the maximum time possible to integrate them into the squad and for Amorim to plot a path for both in the first team.
The duo seem set to occupy the two number 10 roles but that has a knock-on impact elsewhere and having a full summer to fine tune the line-up would be a real positive for the Reds boss.
United have made it clear they want to shift four first teamers.
Rashford, Sancho, Antony and Garnacho have no future at Old Trafford but moving them on, and achieving the desired fees, is easier said than done.

Garnacho has admirers and his ability and talent mean plenty would be willing to pay for his services, while Rashford and Antony enjoyed productive loan spells in the second half of last season that have created something of a market for the pair.
Chelsea opted not to turn Sancho's loan permanent and he is being linked with a move to Turkey.

The issue for United is they are in a weak bargaining position with everyone fully aware they are desperate to offload. That makes driving the price up with potential suitors difficult. How much United are able to rake in from the four could go a long way to defining the success of the summer.
Amorim will be keen to maximise pre-season with his squad to fine tune his style and tactics with the volume of games last season offering precious little time on the training pitch.

United are now set for a first pre-season under the Portuguese coach while the absence of European football could prove a blessing in disguise if it allows Amorim and his coaching staff time to get their methods implented.

Deals for Cunha and Mbuemo would reshape the squad and leave United pretty close to an XI Amorim would want. There remain a couple of gaps in the squad but there is plenty to work with and plenty of time to work.

headline: Dream Marcus Rashford Man United to Barcelona transfer scenario with date set in stone
body: Were Barcelona to act on their interest in Manchester United's Marcus Rashford, all three parties involved can look forward to the dream scenario developing quickly.

Old Trafford chiefs may have hoped Aston Villa would be the ones to eliminate an issue before it sprung, though the Premier League rivals have not taken up their £40m option to sign Rashford at the end of his recent short-term loan. Therefore a new home will have to be found for the 27-year-old who has been out of Ruben Amorim's plans since last December.
Barca sporting director Deco has already openly discussed their interest with the summer transfer window in play, now the latest rumour is of a loan deal for the season ahead.

It might not fetch Man United a fee right away, though the La Liga champions have actually just confirmed their latest major financial boost - one that could help shift Rashford on for good at a later date.

On Wednesday, it was announced Sunday, August 10 will be the date that Barca return to playing home matches at the Spotify Camp Nou. The iconic stadium has been through a £1.25bn restoration project that meant the club have been forced to play elsewhere over the past two seasons.

Originally with capacity of 99,000, the Spanish side moved from Camp Nou to their temporary home at the city's former Olympic Stadium, which holds a reduced 60,000. Their renovated stadium is aiming to house 105,000 - the largest football venue in Europe.

Revenue from ticket sales and all fees supporters are charged with around the match-going experience will serve to drastically increase Barca's income over a period of time and put them in a much more secure financial position to go out to sign their top targets at will.
In Rashford's case, even if just a loan now it will be a dream come true, or so it is said, for him to be a part of a new era with the five-time Champions League winners.
Barca get what they desire most - added depth amongst their pool of wingers - and for Man United it is an opportunity to get a player off the books again for the 2025/26 campaign.

If they offer the La Liga club the same £40m option that Villa were handed, only for next summer's transfer window, they could at least land the fee they have been asking for all this time Rashford has been out of the fold at his boyhood club.
A win, win, win scenario.

headline: Cristiano Ronaldo can help sanction Man United next transfer to hand Ruben Amorim £20m windfall
body: Manchester United have been busy in the summer transfer window with Matheus Cunha through the door and Bryan Mbeumo edging closer to joining him.
The double signing will see United's spending surpass the £120million mark, something that seemed very far-fetched following their Europa League final defeat to Tottenham at the end of May.

United have been forced to splash the cash in the early stages of the transfer window after recording their worst season in 51 years, consequently missing out on European football for the 2025/26 campaign.

Once Mbeumo comes through the door, United will have to place their focus in balancing pursuing more targets and selling players. Some big names could depart Old Trafford this summer but there are doubts over their ability to offload unwanted players such as Alejandro Garnacho, Marcus Rashford and Jadon Sancho.

Casemiro is another player who had seemed to be up for sale but the defensive midfielder enjoyed a resurgence under Ruben Amorim in the second half of last season. However, reports from Saudi Arabia this week have claimed that the Brazilian is close to joining Al-Nassr this summer.

Those reports have gone quiet in the last few days but news of Cristiano Ronaldo's contract extension at the club could accelerate a move. The 40-year-old has agreed a new two-year deal at Al-Nassr, ending speculation about his departure.

According to journalist Santi Aouna, the former United forward has received guarantees from the country's Public Investment Fund to build a competitive team with Ronaldo set to be a 'main decision-maker' in Al-Nassr's squad building.

The journalist has also claimed that Faris Najd wants to sign a new centre-back, defensive midfielder and left winger, at the very least, this summer. After playing with Casemiro previously at United and Real Madrid, Ronaldo could be the key dictator in a third reunion with the Brazilian this summer.

Casemiro isn't expected to bring in a hefty transfer fee that the likes of Garnacho and Antony are valued at, but his reported £375,000-per-week wages being removed from United's wage budget would see a whopping £19.5m saved.
A recent report from The Times has claimed that United will be in the market for a striker, a wing-back, a midfielder and a goalkeeper once Mbeumo signs.

headline: Manchester United defender's next club confirmed as transfer completed
body: Outgoing Manchester United defender Sam Murray has joined non-league side Carlisle United ahead of his Old Trafford contract officially expiring.
The left-back will leave United on June 30 after being informed his contract would not be renewed. He is one of nine players who will leave the club next week.

Murray, 20, has signed a one-year deal with Carlisle, who will play in the National League next season after being relegated from League Two last term. It means he is linking up with former United striker Mark Hughes, who was appointed Carlisle boss in February.
Addressing the addition of Murray, Hughes told the Cumbrians' club website: "We're delighted that Sam is joining us, he's a great young talent who has been at a great club.
"He's a left sided player with good pace and good technical ability, and I'm looking forward to working with him."
Despite playing a key role in United's FA Youth Cup success in 2021/22, Murray failed to make his senior debut during his time at Old Trafford.

He signed his first professional contract at United in May 2023 after being taken to Spain by former United manager Erik ten Hag in December 2022 for the club's mid-season training camp and friendlies against Cadiz and Real Betis during the World Cup break.
Ten Hag also took Murray to Norway for last summer's pre-season opener against Rosenborg and he was handed a start at left-back.
Announcing his departure from United earlier this month, Murray posted on Instagram: "After seven years, my time at Manchester United has come to an end.
"I would like to thank everyone at the club for your support, especially my coaches and teammates over the years.
"It's been a privilege to represent this club, and I will forever be grateful for the opportunities and experience this club has given me. I wish everyone the best of luck for the future."

headline: Manchester United closing in on second transfer of the summer
body: Manchester United are closing in on the signing of Brentford attacker Bryan Mbeumo after submitting a bid in excess of £60million.
The Reds, who have already signed Matheus Cunha from Wolves this summer, offered £45m up front and an additional £10m in add-ons.

Talks between United and Brentford have continued in recent weeks and a deal is now on the brink of being finalised. Despite firm interest from Tottenham Hotspur, Mbeumo recently informed confidants that he wants to join United.
Mbeumo, 25, enjoyed an outstanding 2024/25 campaign for Brentford, scoring 20 Premier League goals to help them achieve a top half finish.
He is out of contract at the Gtech Community Stadium next summer, though Brentford have a one-year option to extend his stay until 2027.

United have identified the former Troyes man as an ideal option to strengthen their attacking ranks. He is a versatile operator, meaning he will be capable of playing as a right wing-back or as a right-sided No.10 in Ruben Amorim's 3-4-2-1 system.
United made strengthening their attacking options their leading priority this summer after finishing last season with a negative goal difference of -10 in the Premier League.
In Cunha and Mbeumo, they are set to add two players who scored 35 league goals between them last term. United scored just 44 goals as a collective.
United still remain keen on adding another attacker to their ranks this summer. It is no secret they are desperate to recruit an out-and-out centre-forward to spearhead their attack.

headline: 'A dream' - wildcard striker option confirms interest in Manchester United transfer
body: Genk striker Tolu Arokodare has said it would "mean a lot" to join Manchester United this summer amid reports linking him with a move to Old Trafford.
The 24-year-old Nigeria international has been linked with a move to United recently after scoring 23 goals in 45 appearances for Belgian club Genk across all competitions last season.
United, who are closing in on the signing of Brentford ace Bryan Mbeumo, are desperate to add a striker to their ranks this summer to beef up their attack.

They installed Liam Delap as their top target prior to the start of the transfer window but have since missed out on his signature to Premier League rivals Chelsea. He was available via a £30million release clause after Ipswich Town were relegated to the Championship.

Arokodare has become the latest striker to be linked with a move to Old Trafford after an impressive 2024/25 campaign saw him chalk up 30 direct goal contributions. And he has admitted he is a United fan and that it is his "dream" to play in the Premier League.
"Obviously, it's a dream to play in the Premier League, but I have my eyes on it for sure," Arokodare told Sports Boom.
"Whatever options I have, I'll take my time and make the best decision.
"I'm a Manchester United fan, and if it happens, it would mean a lot to me and my family. Of course, it would be a dream come true."
Since joining Genk in January 2023, Arokodare has scored a respectable 40 goals in 108 appearances. He has also racked up 12 assists.

headline: Man United one step closer to signing Bryan Mbeumo as Brentford agree transfer
body: Manchester United's second signing of the summer transfer window is getting closer to being completed with Bryan Mbeumo expected to join Matheus Cunha through the door.

Mbeumo enjoyed an outstanding season last term with 20 Premier League goals. The 25-year-old enters the final year of his contract at the Gtech Community Stadium, though Brentford have a one-year option to extend his stay until 2027.

It's hoped that Mbeumo will be signed, sealed and delivered in time to be part of the start of United's pre-season schedule on July 7. Anticipation over the signing has been building among United supporters and Brentford's own transfer business offers further encouragement of seeing Mbeumo in red.

The Mirror have reported that the Bees have agreed a deal to sign Feyenoord's attacking midfielder Antoni Milambo with the transfer expected to progress now the Netherlands Under-21s have crashed out of the U21 European Championships.

A deal worth an initial £17m plus £4.25m in bonuses has been in the works for two months after Thomas Frank, who has now left the club, personally approved the deal. A verbal agreement on personal terms has also been in place for over a month meaning a deal is close to being finalised.

Brentford are seemingly acting swiftly to get new faces through the door before their influx of cash. Alongside Mbeumo and the £60m+ to be received from United, they are also set to receive an estimated £10m plus bonuses from Arsenal for club captain Christian Norgaard.

headline: Oldham Athletic, Stockport County and Salford City EFL fixtures in full as trio discover opponents
body: Oldham Athletic will face MK Dons at Stadium MK in their first game back in the English Football League on Saturday, August 2.

The Latics were promoted back to the EFL at the beginning of June after beating Southend United 3-2 in the National League play-off final at Wembley. Kian Harratt's extra-time winner ended their three-year exile from the EFL.

After facing MK Dons, who are one of the favourites for promotion from League Two next season, on the opening day, Micky Mellon's side will welcome Colchester United in their first home game of the campaign on Saturday, August 9.
Boxing Day will see the Latics travel to the coast to face Grimsby Town at Blundell Park. They will conclude their first season back in the EFL with a home game against Accrington Stanley on May 2.

Elsewhere, League Two counterparts and neighbours Salford City will start the season at home to Crewe Alexandra on August 2. They will then travel to Notts County, who were beaten in last season's play-off semi-finals, in their second game of the campaign.
The Ammies will bring the curtain down on their 2025/26 campaign with a trip to Crawley Town on May 2.

In League One, Stockport County will begin the process of trying to bounce back from last term's play-off semi-final defeat to Leyton Orient with an opening day clash against Bolton Wanderers at Edgeley Park. The contest has been pencilled in for a 12pm kick-off on Sunday, August 3.
They will bring their campaign to an end with a trip to Oakwell to face Barnsley on May 2.

headline: The nine players who will definitely leave Manchester United next week
body: Nine players will officially leave Manchester United when their contracts expire on Monday.
United issued their retained list earlier this month, confirming who will be released when their deals expire at the end of June.

The headline departures from Old Trafford will be Victor Lindelof, Jonny Evans and Christian Eriksen. United confirmed the trio would be leaving the club ahead of submitting their retained list to the Premier League.
In addition to Lindelof, Evans and Eriksen, United will also say farewell to six academy players.

Goalkeepers Hubert Graczyk, Tom Wooster and Tom Myles were informed they would not be receiving new deals, likewise James Nolan, Sam Murray and Jack Kingdon. Myles, Wooster, Nolan and Kingdon all spent time out on loan last season.
Tom Heaton's deal is also due to expire next Monday, but United confirmed at the time of issuing their retained list they were in talks with the veteran shot-stopper over a new deal.
United are in the market for a new goalkeeper this summer, meaning their decision to tie Heaton down to a new deal suggests Altay Bayindir may be sold.
Heaton is unlikely to have been retained with a view to being demoted to fourth in the pecking order.

Andre Onana has attracted interest from AS Monaco recently but wants to stay at Old Trafford. He is preparing for the forthcoming campaign under the assumption he will remain the club's first-choice goalkeeper.

headline: Manchester United are committing to Ruben Amorim's long-term transfer plan
body: Before Manchester United had even unveiled Ruben Amorim as their new head coach last November, almost all the conversation was about his preferred 3-4-2-1 system.
United identified Amorim as their first-choice candidate to replace Erik ten Hag and moved at speed to extract him from Sporting Lisbon.
Much of Amorim's success in Portugal stemmed from his unique system. With United in desperate need of new ideas, it was inevitable they would transition to a three-at-the-back formation.
Indeed, Amorim confirmed what everyone anticipated when he set up with a back three for his first game in charge against Ipswich Town at Portman Road.
The system means width is provided by the wing-backs, who are responsible for being equally comfortably defensively and offensively. Amad and Diogo Dalot were the first to be tasked with that role.

Eight months on, Patrick Dorgu looks set to go into next season as United's first choice left wing-back. Amad will face competition from Noussair Mazraoui, Dalot and potentially Bryan Mbeumo on the opposite flank.
Prior to Amorim's appointment, Amad was considered as a natural winger; he is now considered as a wing-back or a No.10. He is equally effective in either role.

Amad's adaptability to Amorim's 3-4-2-1 has been admirable. He is the only member of United's pool of wingers from the beginning of last season that is guaranteed to still be at the club come the start of next term.
United are prioritising the sales of Marcus Rashford, Jadon Sancho and Antony this summer and are also open to selling Alejandro Garnacho at the right price. None of them fit into Amorim's system.

Rashford, Sancho and Antony all spent time out on loan last season and United hope to sell each of them on a permanent basis. Rashford is valued at £40million, Antony is available for £32.58m and Sancho is expected to command a fee in the region of £20m.

Garnacho, who was the subject of a £40m offer from Napoli in January, is set to command a fee north of £50m, meaning United could find themselves banking a healthy sum of money for four players that do not fit into Amorim's system.

United need to raise funds via players sales to bring in new recruits this summer and they are trying to use their natural wingers as sources of revenue. There is value and logic in attempting to offload players who simply do not fit into Amorim's system.
As chief executive Omar Berrada explained back in March, United will only commit to sales this summer that will benefit the team.

"We need to be cautious and, and we need to try to make as many good decisions as we can in recruitment," said Berrada. "And also when it comes to sales, we will do it purely on the basis of whether it helps improve the team or not, not for financial reasons."
Rashford and Garnacho rank as two of the most sellable assets within the squad, but United would not be actively looking to sell them this summer if they had important roles to play.
By attempting to sell them, plus Sancho and Antony, United's hierarchy are in full support of Amorim. They are also showing they are in full support of his 3-4-2-1 system.

On the flip side, if United experience a rocky start to next season and feel they have no choice but to sack Amorim in search of an upturn in results, they may feel obliged to recruit a replacement well-versed in a three-at-the-back formation.
United are in need of a sense of stability and supporters are fully behind Amorim, confident he will turn the club's fortunes around after a first summer transfer window at the helm.
With the sales of wingers being prioritised, it shows that United's hierarchy are in full support of Amorim and his philosophy.

headline: LUCKHURST: Manchester United have made a change with Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo deals
body: It was noticeable during Omar Berrada's first summer as Manchester United chief executive that the club never broke the £60million barrier for a signing.

For years, Berrada's former employers at Manchester City privately bragged that they seldom spent more than £60m on a player. Jose Mourinho felt he was on a hiding to nothing against a state-backed club but it was a matter of quality more than quantity with City.

To date, City have spent in excess of that figure on only four players: Rodri, Ruben Dias, Jack Grealish and Josko Gvardiol. Grealish is the sole failure and his best season still coincided with City's treble triumph.
Leny Yoro was United's most expensive acquisition last year for an up front fee of £52.18m. The deal could total £58.91m.

Already this summer, United have crept above the £60m mark for Matheus Cunha, who had a reasonable release clause of £62.5m. Bryan Mbeumo, who outscored Cunha and everyone else in the Premier League bar Erling Haaland, Alexander Isak and Mohamed Salah, could fetch an identical fee.

That is the going rate for a Premier League-standard forward. Only one of United's five arrivals last year was an attacker and Joshua Zirkzee also had a release clause. He was based in Italy, whose league has been in decline for nearly two decades and has become a dumping ground for English clubs. Ie. not United material but nearly as economical as Jasprit Bumrah's bowling.

Sensibly, United have sought forwards with Premier League pedigree this year. Liam Delap was another they wanted on board and the eventual identity of their new No.9 (to consider Cunha or Mbeumo as one would be a complete cop-out) will be curious as it is unlikely to be a domestic deal.

Before he purged his Twitter account, Berrada revelled in how much United had overpaid for Angel di Maria in 2014. Di Maria, a reigning Champions League winner who had recently helped Argentina to reach the World Cup final, commanded a British-record £59.7m fee.

The problem with Di Maria was not the fee but the fact that he did not want to move to Manchester. United had a free run as Paris Saint-Germain, Di Maria's preferred choice, were out of the running due to financial fair play issues.
Di Maria effectively covered the cost of James Rodriguez, Madrid's vanity signing. They still had change to get Toni Kroos, possibly the bargain of the decade, at £20m.

Ed Woodward had also incepted the United tax by signing Marouane Fellaini for £4.5m more than was necessary in 2013. Back when FFP was not an issue for United and profitability and sustainability rules had not entered the football lexicon, Woodward operated as though spending inflated fees was a sound strategy. Luke Shaw became football's most expensive teenager two months before Di Maria was driven through the barriers at Carrington.

Erik ten Hag aimed high in the Premier League market and the price was not right for United. They were not in the running when Declan Rice was available in 2023, having already earmarked Mason Mount as their central midfield target, and refused to test the waters with Tottenham for Harry Kane.

Those two England internationals cost £187m combined when they moved to Arsenal and Bayern Munich. The negotiations of those deals involved 'big six' clubs, whereas Cunha and Mbeumo are more affordable, having operated outside of the elite, and are not England internationals.

Brentford were looking for between £50m and £60m for Ivan Toney last year until it transpired that no Premier League clubs would meet them at the table. That drove his price down to £40m for Al Ahli. Mbeumo, in contrast, generated interest from Tottenham Hotspur and Newcastle United and outperformed any of Toney's top-flight campaigns before he decided on United. So he was never going to be as cheap.

£60m is a figure that came to define United's 2023 summer window, one of their worst. Everyone at the club maintained that was the maximum they would pay for Rasmus Hojlund. Eventually, they overpaid with a final package of £72m.

On the eve of the 2024 window, Berrada warned United would be on a "slippery slope" if they overpaid clubs, players and agents. Their spending was more disciplined, even if it eventually totalled £206m, but this year it is needs must after United's worst season in 51 years. A little more than £120m for two of the best forwards in the Premier League last season is a statement.

United have made savings through their existence outside of the Champions League. For the third season out of four, players will be on a reduced salary due to their failure to qualify for the competition again.

Two rounds of redundancies and slashing the non-playing workforce by roughly a third have also freed up funds after a decrease of £20m year-on-year on employee benefit expenses. United's net cash inflow of £22.3m during the last quarter was an increase of £7.2m from the same quarter last year.

Sir Jim Ratcliffe's remark that United could have gone "bust" by Christmas always sounded like scaremongering. PSR has genuinely compromised them (they loaned in Wout Weghorst as Cristiano Ronaldo's mid-season replacement when Cody Gakpo was available), only it was undermined by squandering £625.43m under Ten Hag.
United's market movement under Berrada has been hitherto inoffensive but the greater the price, the greater the scrutiny. And United are now going north of £60m.

headline: Man United have already decided on their next three signings if they seal Bryan Mbeumo transfer
body: Manchester United hope to strengthen their attack, midfield and goalkeeping department if they get a deal over the line for Brentford star Bryan Mbeumo.
After seeing an opening offer of £55million turned down by the Bees earlier this month, United have submitted a new bid in excess of £60m.

Despite already strengthening their attack with the addition of Matheus Cunha, United are determined to bring Mbeumo to Old Trafford after he scored 20 Premier League goals last season. The Cameroonian has informed confidants of his desire to move to M16.
Only three players scored more Premier League goals than Mbeumo last term, meaning he would be a statement signing if United were to get a deal over the line.

If United are successful in their efforts, Mbeumo will become another significant cog in United's attack. They have already added to Ruben Amorim's pool of attacking options this summer by signing Cunha from Wolves for £62.5m.

United have prioritised strengthening their attacking department this summer after finishing with a goal difference of -10 in the Premier League last season. They also recorded a minus tally in 2023/24.

Although Cunha and potentially Mbeumo will add goals and assists to United's attack, they are determined to sign a striker. However, after missing out on Liam Delap to Chelsea, it remains to be seen in which direction their search for a goal-getter will head in.

A cluster of strikers are continuing to be linked with moves to M16, such as Viktor Gyokeres and Victor Osimhen, but any hopes of United signing a striker of their quality will rest on outgoings. They are yet to oversee a sale this summer.

Doubts have also been shared about Manuel Ugarte's ability on the ball. Amid the likelihood of Cunha becoming United's left-sided No.10 next term, Bruno Fernandes is expected to occupy one of the two central midfield positions, meaning the club is expected to be looking for an ideal midfield partner for him.

Following the club's decision to give Tom Heaton a new deal and the fact Onana is preparing for the new campaign under the assumption of remaining United's No.1, Altay Bayindir is the most likely to exit the goalkeeping department, meaning any incoming will most likely become Onana's deputy.
Elsewhere, the addition of a specialist right wing-back has not been fully dismissed, but Mbeumo could also offer Amorim an option out wide if he arrives from Brentford.

headline: Every Premier League VAR blunder and the worst-affected teams confirmed as Man United figure heavily
body: The Premier League's Key Match Incidents panel has pinpointed 18 VAR errors throughout the 2024-25 season, marking an improvement on the previous year.

All 20 clubs in the league cast their votes on retaining VAR ahead of the season, with Wolves being the sole club advocating for its complete removal. Despite the league's decision to continue with Video Assistant Referees, there were widespread appeals for modifications to enhance the process.

Premier League clubs argued for more frequent and improved training for referees to better the current state of play. They also requested for fixed teams of VAR officials to foster better understanding among officials, as well as advocating for a drastic reduction in delays and improved communication for fans in stadiums, with the latter being a recurring concern for match-going supporters.
The Key Match Officials panel consists of former players and/or coaches, along with one representative each from the Premier League and PGMOL.

ESPN has highlighted the errors identified by the panel over the course of the most recent Premier League season. Here's some further insight into the mistakes - as well as which clubs were affected most.
The first VAR error occurred on the season's opening weekend. Bournemouth striker Ouattara believed he had netted a late winner, only for it to be disallowed due to handball.

The KMI panel unanimously agreed that VAR made an incorrect decision. That extra point for Newcastle proved beneficial, as Eddie Howe's team qualified for the Champions League based solely on goal difference, although it's overly simplistic to claim that a decision on the opening weekend was the deciding factor.
Another unanimous vote here. Fernandes received a straight red card during Manchester United's home defeat to Tottenham in September, with all five panellists deeming it a mistake.
United were 1-0 down at the time and ended up losing 3-0. Fernandes' suspension was eventually overturned on appeal.
The KMI panel votes on both the referee and the VAR in these cases. As with the Ouattara incident, the panel unanimously supported the on-field referee but disagreed with the VAR intervention.

Initially, no penalty was given after United defender De Ligt tackled West Ham forward Danny Ings late in the second half. A lengthy VAR review led referee Michael Oliver to award a penalty, which Jarrod Bowen successfully converted from 12 yards to secure the win for West Ham.
Brentford skipper Norgaard was sent off in the first half of their stalemate at Everton after a challenge on goalkeeper Jordan Pickford, which led to VAR stepping in.

The decision was contentious, with ESPN reporting that the panel was divided (3:2), stating: "The panel were split (3:2), with the majority deeming the on-field decision correct as 'both players are committed to normal footballing actions.' Two panelists deemed the on-field decision incorrect as 'whilst this was a challenge for the ball, there was a high, full and forceful contact with the studs.'".
VAR's hesitance to intervene has also been questioned, particularly regarding Maatsen's tackle on Ismaila Sarr, which some argue warranted a red card.
The debate hinges on whether Maatsen's foul on Sarr prevented a clear scoring chance. Despite the referee and VAR not finding sufficient evidence of this, the panel remained unconvinced.

Not every controversial decision had a significant impact on the game's result. In the match where Everton dominated Wolves with a three-goal lead, the panel still found fault with what they considered an erroneous call.

Doucoure was deemed not to be interfering with play while in an offside position in the build-up to a Craig Dawson own goal. Interestingly, Everton had a goal disallowed for a similar offence earlier in the match, but were not penalised on this occasion.

The match between Forest and Villa in December saw late drama, with the home side scoring twice in the final five minutes to turn defeat into victory. However, the VAR controversy occurred early on, with the scores still level.

Villa appealed for a penalty as Forest's Anderson pulled back Morgan Rogers, but it was not awarded. The KMI panel argued, with a 3-2 majority, that there was sufficient holding in the box to warrant a penalty.

The match between West Ham and Brighton in December saw all the drama unfold after half-time. Mats Wieffer and Mohammed Kudus scored, while Brighton's Estupinan risked a late red card for serious foul play.

Neither the on-field referee nor the VAR felt the Ecuadorian deserved to be dismissed for his foul on Max Kilman, but the KMI panel disagreed. "The action of Estupinian has speed, force, intensity and endangers the safety of the opponent," they stated.
Just a week later, another Brighton player avoided a red card. Joao Pedro threw an elbow at Brentford's Yehor Yarmoliuk but remained on the pitch.
Despite making no contact with his opponent, the Brazilian should not have avoided a red card, according to the KMI panel, who unanimously agreed that the officials made an error.

In December, West Ham found themselves on the wrong end of a VAR penalty mistake, having previously benefited from one in October. The Hammers may feel this could have significantly impacted the game, as their 1-0 deficit ballooned into a 5-0 loss following the decision.

Mac Allister was seen throwing Carlos Soler to the ground off the ball, leading to a split decision among the KMI panel, with some arguing it had no impact on play. This defeat marked Julen Lopetegui's final match at the London Stadium, as he was sacked following a loss to Manchester City days later.

Brighton, who had previously benefited from VAR errors in December, found themselves on the receiving end in January. The Seagulls appealed for an early penalty at Ipswich after Burns obstructed Jan Paul van Hecke, but the appeal was dismissed.
Ultimately, it didn't make much difference, as Fabian Hurzeler's side went on to secure a 2-0 victory.

Nottingham Forest's encounter with Southampton in January proved a nail-biter when it really shouldn't have. A comfortable 3-0 advantage was unnervingly slashed to 3-2, in part due to the controversy surrounding a disallowed goal which potentially could have halted Southampton's comeback.

Milenkovic was under the impression he had extended the lead to 4-1 just after Saints' initial strike, only to see his effort ruled out for an offside decision against his colleague Chris Wood. The expert panel, nevertheless, agreed that Wood did not interfere with play and the goal should have stood.

In the Wolves vs Arsenal clash, Myles Lewis-Skelly was shown a red card before the break at Molineux for halting a counter. There was little dispute over the foul on Matt Doherty warranting action, yet the severity of the card caught Arsenal off guard.

Despite being a player down, Arsenal clinched victory, and Wolves concluded the match similarly handicapped, seeing one of their own dismissed. Following a review, Lewis-Skelly's red card was rescinded.
"Yeah obviously really happy that the decision has been made and Myles is going to be available for us," said Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta.

It wasn't until April, after these contentious January moments, that another dubious VAR outcome emerged, as acknowledged by the KMI panel. However, this instance marked the first of two contentious calls made on that same day.
Hinshelwood's challenge on Jacob Ramsey was overlooked by officials, and despite Villa claiming it was a clear penalty, they won the game 3-0.

James Tarkowski was only booked for a contentious tackle on Alexis Mac Allister. The KMI panel unanimously agreed that despite winning the ball first, the dangerousness of Tarkowski's action warranted a red card, stating: "The clear dangerous nature of the challenge is not mitigated by Tarkowski winning the ball first," and identified it as "A clear example of endangering the safety of an opponent."

Fulham, hosting Liverpool at Craven Cottage, won 3-2, marking just the second league defeat for the Reds this season in April. Fulham managed to overcome being denied a valid penalty when Liverpool's goalkeeper Caoimhin Kelleher fouled Andreas Pereira without receiving any consequence.
United's game with Bournemouth also saw VAR controversy. The game ended in a draw after the home side had led, even though Evanilson's red card stirred debate over referee decisions once again.

Evanilson was shown the red card following a tackle on United's Noussair Mazraoui. However, it seemed he slipped into the challenge, a point noted in the panel's explanation, leading to the Brazilian's ban being ultimately rescinded.

Our list concludes with relegated Ipswich, who were already relegated when they received an inconsequential reprieve against Brentford. Defender Tuanzebe pulled Bees' Nathan Collins to the turf, but no penalty was given.

The panel contended that the grappling between the players was not mutual, with Tuanzebe clutching his opponent with both arms. The decision had no impact on the outcome, as Brentford were 1-0 up at the time and won by the same margin.
So, who benefited the most... and who suffered.

Brentford bore the brunt of these incorrect decisions, finding themselves on the losing side three times without benefiting from a mistake even once. On the flip side are Everton, who profited three times without any losses.

ESPN also examined the biggest beneficiaries of VAR decisions - not just the errors listed above - throughout the season. Newcastle lead the pack in this regard, with 13 decisions in their favour and only four against, while Bournemouth are at the opposite end with four decisions for them and 11 against.

Three teams - Chelsea, Leicester and Manchester City - experienced no VAR errors throughout the entire season. In fact, City only had four VAR interventions in their matches all season - three in their favour and one against.

headline: LUCKHURST: Onana stance on United future amid Monaco transfer links
body: Andre Onana remains intent on staying at Manchester United and will only consider leaving if the club want to sell him.
Onana has been preparing under the assumption he will still be at United next season and coach Ruben Amorim wants to keep the 29-year-old.
Monaco have been linked with a move for Onana after they qualified for the Champions League by finishing third in Ligue 1 last season.
United have not budgeted to recruit a new No.1 amid their focus on enhancing their attack and staff at the club have offered private backing for Onana.

Onana has failed to live up this game-changing billing since he moved to United from Inter Milan for £47.2million in July 2023. He committed costly errors in the Premier League defeats to Nottingham Forest, Wolves and Brighton last season before he was culpable for both of Lyon's goals in United's 2-2 Europa League quarter-final first leg draw in April.

On the eve of that game, the Lyon midfielder Nemanja Matic dubbed Onana "one of the worst goalkeepers in the history of Man United" after the Cameroonian claimed United were "way better" than Lyon. Amorim rested Onana for United's next match away to Newcastle United.
Onana is under contract at United until 2028 and the club would require a fee of £28.32million to sell him without making a loss under the Premier League's profitability and sustainability rules.
Onana's switch to the LIAN Sports Group agency earlier this year was not with a view to a summer transfer.
He has played 101 times for United and kept 24 clean sheets.

headline: Liverpool lead biggest transfer summer spenders as Kerkez takes them near £200m
body: Chelsea are bidding to be the world’s biggest spenders in the summer window for the fourth consecutive season, but Manchester City and Liverpool have overtaken them for now.
All fees and figures are taken from Transfermarkt. The 20 biggest deals of the summer are here.

10) Burnley – £49.27m
There has been a slew of converted loans and then the first ‘new’ signing has arrived in the form of goalkeeper Max Weiss, perhaps precipitating James Trafford’s move to Newcastle. Quickly followed by the improbably named Quilindschy Hartman.

9) Brighton – £51.3m
Perhaps in an effort to ensure Fabian Hurzeler has enough of an age gap over at least some of his squad, Brighton have spent a fair whack on three exciting teenagers from Sunderland, Daejeon Hana Citizen and Olympiacos, and the 21-year-old Diego Coppola.

8) Borussia Dortmund – £52.48m
They used the Club World Cup transfer window to bring in Jobe Bellingham and Yan Couto and they could add Jason Sancho.

7) Tottenham – £60.52m
That’s a decent whack of money spent on Kevin Danso, Mathys Tel and Luka Vuskovic before Thomas Frank even gets a say.

6) Juventus – £62.27m
Every penny has so far been spent on making loan signings permanent, with Nico Gonzalez their most expensive purchase.

5) Manchester United – £62.5m
They have completed the most expensive transfer of the summer so far with the capture of Wolves maverick Matheus Cunha, with Bryan Mbeumo possibly to follow. We’re not sure where all this money is coming from…

4) Chelsea – £99.1m
They were the top spenders in the summers of 2024, 2023 and 2022 and will be up there in 2025 thanks to pre-arranged moves for Estevao, Dario Essugo, Mamadou Sarr and Kendry Paez. Throw in the £30m signing of Liam Delap and the Blues are already making very expensive waves.

3) Real Madrid – £100.5m

headline: Manchester United is still right place for Kobbie Mainoo despite PSR temptation
body: England were a lot of things at Euro 2024 but spectacular wasn’t one of them. Reaching the final and getting within five minutes of winning the trophy speaks for itself and the Three Lions, gradually, found their way after a dull start. They were never exciting. They just found their way.

Manchester United midfielder Kobbie Mainoo was a big part of that small improvement. He barely played in a group stage that was worryingly tame but started all four matches of a more controlled, more effective knock-out phase.

Mainoo turned 20 in April. He’s proven his worth in an England shirt. He’s a Stockport-born United academy graduate with 50 Premier League appearances under his belt. That his future isn’t completely certain this summer is an indictment not only of the club, but of football’s financial governance.

Specifically, it highlights the flaws in football’s financial governance frameworks. In the Premier League, profit and sustainability rules (PSR) allow clubs to make a £105m loss in any given three-year period.
Because teams are on an endless quest for improvement on the pitch, players need to be bought and sold. In the PSR era, those sales are increasingly coming from the ‘Do Not Sell’ pile.

Profit from sales is booked immediately and transfer fees are amortised over the lengths of the players’ contracts. Clubs sell players with value to pay down their losses and replace them with expensive successors, whose futures will be subject to the same calculations down the line.

United themselves are pertinent to the PSR debate – if debts aren’t part of the calculation and clubs have to sell players against their wishes on June 30 only to buy someone more expensive on July 1 to comply with allowable losses, is it really doing its job? – but the basic fact of the matter is this: Manchester United shouldn’t be considering the sale of Mainoo in a million months of Super Sundays.
And yet they might. It’s the same with Alejandro Garnacho, albeit the winger’s departure would be welcomed more positively given his penchant for bridge-burning.
Mainoo and Garnacho did not command transfer fees on the way in but would on the way out, and that helps United equip Ruben Amorim with Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo.
